qas.question: What did the Duke of York require every community in his lands to support?
Instead of Anglican, what were the churches most often supported in New York and New Jersey?
What were taxpayers free to do after they paid the Duke of York his local tax?
Why was the Duke not a friend of Anglicanism?
When did the first Anglican minister arrive in New Jersey?
What did the Duke of York never require every community in his lands to support?
Instead of Anglican, what were the churches never supported in New York and New Jersey?
What were taxpayers not free to do after they paid the Duke of York his local tax?
Why was the Duke a friend of Anglicanism?
When did the first Anglican minister leave New Jersey?

context: The Duke of York had required that every community in his new lands of New York and New Jersey support <a0_0><b5_0>some church<b5_0/><a0_0/>, but this was more often <a1_0><b6_0>Dutch Reformed, Quaker or Presbyterian<b6_0/><a1_0/>, than Anglican. Some chose to support more than one church. He also ordained that the tax-payers were free, having paid his local tax, <a2_0>to <b7_0>choose their own church<b7_0/><a2_0/>. The terms for the surrender of New Amsterdam had provided that the Dutch would have liberty of conscience, and the Duke, as an <a3_0><b8_0>openly divine-right<b8_0/> Catholic,<a3_0/> was no friend of Anglicanism. The first Anglican minister in New Jersey arrived in <a4_0><b9_0>1698<b9_0/><a4_0/>, though Anglicanism was more popular in New York.
